content: It's pretty hard to google this up because of all the talk about free monads that comes up. Are there any interesting things we can say about a monad where all algebras are free algebras, particularly if there's a nice equivalence (coreflective maybe) between the Eilenberg-Moore and Kleisli categories?
There's been some discussion on MathOverflow about this in the past, e.g. Varieties where every algebra is free.

particularly if there's a nice equivalence (coreflective maybe) between the Eilenberg-Moore and Kleisli categories

Note that every equivalence can be strengthened to an [[adjoint equivalence]], so we don't gain anything by restricting to "nice" equivalences.
I gave a talk on this topic at some point of my life.
It's nice when the nice equivalence is the easily available one.

Nathanael Arkor said:

There's been some discussion on MathOverflow about this in the past, e.g. Varieties where every algebra is free.

Wow, that is some seriously strong result! My monad is not going to be on Set though. (The prototypical cases are on "interesting" presheaf categories.)
The talk is very interesting and even though it also deals with stable monads on Set it makes the underlying ideas more approachable.

My own examples are completion under degeneracies in a presheaf category, for example, completion from semisimplicial to simplicial sets. Aside from being stable they are "essentially unary" in that the action of the monad on the subobject lattice preserves meets and joins.

Say you have a left adjoint monad TTT, which is also Cartesian. Call the right adjoint DDD. Consider an algebra TA→a‾ATA \xrightarrow{\overline{a}} ATAa​A and its adjunct coalgebra A→a‾DAA \xrightarrow[\underline{a}]{} DAAa​​DA. Is it possible to prove that a‾\overline{a}a is free on a subobject of AAA? If not, what if TTT is strongly Cartesian?
Never mind, I found a counterexample. It comes down to the fact that every degenerate cell is a degeneracy of a unique cell but not necessarily in a unique way.

Take BBB to be the pushout of the kernel pair of a‾\overline{a}a. This has a natural comparison morphism χ\chiχ into AAA that gives two factorizations of a‾\overline{a}a. Consider the free algebra on this object, TTB→μTBTTB \xrightarrow{\mu} TBTTBμ​TB. Since TTT preserves pullbacks and pushouts, TBTBTB is constructed from Ta‾T\overline{a}Ta in the same way BBB is constructed from a‾\overline{a}a, and it has a comparison morphism to TATATA which has to be TχT\chiTχ. Take a‾∘Tχ\overline{a}\circ{}T\chia∘Tχ as a comparison between μB\mu_{B}μB​ and a‾\overline{a}a. a‾∘T(a‾∘Tχ)=a‾∘Ta‾∘TTχ=a‾∘μA∘TTχ=a‾∘Tχ∘μB\overline{a}\circ{}T(\overline{a}\circ{}T\chi) = \overline{a}\circ{}T\overline{a}\circ{}TT\chi = \overline{a}\circ{}\mu_A\circ{}TT\chi = \overline{a}\circ{}T\chi\circ\mu_Ba∘T(a∘Tχ)=a∘Ta∘TTχ=a∘μA​∘TTχ=a∘Tχ∘μB​, so it is a legit morphism. Now let's build it an inverse.

Morphisms into TBTBTB are not easy to build since it is a pushout, but there is already δ:TA×ATA→B\delta : TA \times_A TA \to Bδ:TA×A​TA→B that's pretty canonical. What's more, χ∘δ\chi\circ\deltaχ∘δ is the common diagonal of the pushout square involving AAA. So a‾∘Tχ∘Tδ=a‾∘Ta‾∘Tp1=a‾∘μA∘Tp1\overline{a}\circ{}T\chi\circ{}T\delta = \overline{a}\circ{}T\overline{a}\circ{}Tp_1 = \overline{a}\circ\mu_A\circ{}Tp_1a∘Tχ∘Tδ=a∘Ta∘Tp1​=a∘μA​∘Tp1​. Still need to invert that, so take the morphism η~\tilde{\eta}η~​ that factors ηA\eta_AηA​ through TA×ATATA \times_A TATA×A​TA. a‾∘μA∘Tp1∘Tη~∘ηA=a‾∘μA∘TηA∘ηA=a‾∘ηA=idA\overline{a}\circ\mu_A\circ{}Tp_1\circ{}T\tilde{\eta}\circ\eta_A = \overline{a}\circ\mu_A\circ{}T\eta_A\circ\eta_A = \overline{a}\circ\eta_A = \mathrm{id}_Aa∘μA​∘Tp1​∘Tη~​∘ηA​=a∘μA​∘TηA​∘ηA​=a∘ηA​=idA​.

I can't seem to prove it's more than a semi-inverse though. It feels like the right thing because it glues together everything that can become equal through operations in TTT, but I'm not quite getting it.
